column42: I worked with an NGO in Brazil.  I asked them what their needs are / what would be helpful. They didn't know what was feasible, so I did a site visit to understand their values/goals and also got access to their internal data platform. Based on that, I developed 5 brief project ideas and shared them on a GoogleDoc. Then we met via Zoom, and their staff said that one of the ideas would clearly be the most helpful, so I focused on that. It was to use ecosystem service analysis tools to prioritize riparian reforestation areas based on where they would have the most ecosystem service benefits (carbon sequestration and water quality). They are already using it to prioritize reforestation planting areas.

column8: I define success as building trust and relationships with community, designing a project that community members are excited about, translating the project into meeting actionable deliverables for community members. I also see success as being able to acquire and sustain funding for the project so that it can outlast my work as a researcher.

column42: In collaboration with an organization that focuses on environmental justice - the project was initiated by community members who approached institutional researchers with clear objectives. We worked together to find a shared solution and methods plan - the results of the project were leveraged by community members to advocate for policy change, which they successfully achieved. The relationship is still ongoing between the institutional and community partners despite this project happening ~2 years ago.

column42:
https://ambassadors.openaq.org/
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kk1rJJ5Bdio
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CbkX8EoRaPo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ar4OabsdWdI
https://thrivingearthexchange.org/project/madison-al/
https://thrivingearthexchange.org/projects/?3494300366=12820

Basically - if the projects are time-bound and have nuclear funding, that is enough motivation for the actors to finish a small-scale project. Then, they find motivation to continue looking for funding, or move forward with the project because they already have established the relationships with their stakeholders.

What hasn't worked in general is that when it is a volunteer-led effort and those who are passionate volunteers also tend to live rich lives full of other priorities (family, day job, etc) :-) so it could be difficult to find time with them and things move quite slow. In other cases, actors tend to become self-serving and the volunteerism/engagement is more of a career move; so when their engagement is over and a project is done, they are ready to move on to a different career-building move.

column42: I have a project studying prison environmental injustice in the U.S. From the start of the project (in collaboration with researchers from MIT), a grassroots organization called The Campaign to Fight Toxic Prisons has been involved from the initial grant proposal writing stage and had a representative as a Co-PI on the project. This co-development of datasets and an interactive web application has resulted in deliverables that the organizations and community can actually use and need to carry out their efforts.

column42: Coming up with a user guide for a GIS model that was created for the international potato center to look for suitable areas to grow potatoes in the Parque de la Papa. It's important to give organizations documentation which explains the processes that were used so they can reproduce them.
column43: You should incorporate more of the community partners perspective when working with a group. This can be talked about through correspondence and feedback received from the partner.
